                AP Photo 

                        The GOP pins its hopes on the prosecutor in the Aurora theater massacre case.

            By 
Manu Raju

09/01/15, 05:08 AM EDT

                Updated 08/31/15, 10:39 PM EDT
DENVER — Republicans started this election cycle with a big target in Colorado: The seat occupied by Michael Bennet was seen as their one, probably only, chance to beat a sitting Democratic senator. 
Instead, it’s been one setback after another for the GOP. The state Republican Party has been racked by drama made for an HBO series, capped by a coup attempt targeting its chairman amid charges of blackmail and infidelity. A coveted prospective candidate, Rep. Mike Coffman, decided not to run for the seat. And big-spending GOP groups have poured millions of dollars into efforts to defend vulnerable GOP incumbents — instead of pummeling the 50-year-old, first-term Bennet.
The stakes for the party go well beyond a single Senate seat. Win in this perennial swing state and the GOP’s chances of hanging onto the Senate in a very tough year would improve dramatically. A strong candidate could also help the party compete in what’s expected to be a hard-fought battle for the state’s nine electoral votes in the presidential race.
Now the party is pinning its hopes squarely on one man: George Brauchler, a polished but politically unproven district attorney who prosecuted the man convicted of gunning down a dozen people in the 2012 movie theater massacre in Aurora, Colorado. The 45-year-old prosecutor is under pressure from the party to take on Bennet — in the season of Trump, they see him as someone who could claim the “outsider” mantle — and to jump in soon. 
“I think if he ran for the Senate, he’d be someone who a lot of Republicans could get behind — including myself,” said Sen. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.), who unseated Democratic Sen. Mark Udall in a hotly contested race last year. “I think there are a lot of people who are very interested in this race. I think a lot of them are waiting on George Brauchler.”

2016

            By 
Rachael Bade
             and 
Josh Gerstein

In an interview with POLITICO last week as the theater trial wrapped up, Brauchler said he’s weighing a bid and would decide “relatively soon.” 
“The biggest thing for me right now is I’ve got to get some distance between me and the case,” he said.
There’s no clear Plan B for Republicans if Brauchler passes. They’re reaching out to business executives — including a nephew of Mitt Romney’s — and other wealthy, if politically inexperienced, types who could underwrite a campaign against Bennet and his stocked war chest.
Bennet, who prevailed in a nail-biter in 2010 to win his first full term, said in an interview his biggest hurdle is being an incumbent when voters seem to be even more anti-Washington than usual. He’s trying to pitch himself as a get-things-done pragmatist who’s worked with Republicans on issues like immigration, education and pharmaceutical policy.
But he’s fully cognizant it’s not an easy sell in this environment.
“Just the sort of general anti-incumbent sentiment in the country is probably the thing that I know I’m going to face,” Bennet said when asked about his challenges. ”Somehow we’ve to create a political conversation in this country where the arsonists aren’t the ones who are getting away with complaining that the place is on fire.”
Sitting outside a Starbucks on a sweltering afternoon here last week, Bennet warned his party not to take his seat for granted.
“I can’t say it another way: It will be close, I know it will be close,” said Bennet, a former superintendent of Denver public schools and Yale-educated lawyer who was first appointed to his seat in 2009. “I’ve been telling everybody nationally that that’s true.”
Colorado is a rare pickup opportunity for Republicans next year. There are 24 GOP seats up this cycle vs. just 10 for Democrats. Of those 10, Bennet is the only incumbent seeking reelection who’s considered at risk. 
Even then, Bennet has a clear leg up: No Republican White House hopeful has won the state since 2004, and no GOP Senate candidate has won in a presidential year since 1996. On top of that, an influx of Hispanic and younger voters moving into the state bodes well for Bennet, especially with a presidential race sure to drive turnout higher.
“Having survived 2010, which was brutal, I don’t mind confessing that I’m glad I’m running in a presidential year — so I think that will be a big difference,” said Bennet, who defeated now-Rep. Ken Buck by less than 2 points five years ago.



            By 
Philip Ewing

So far, at least, national conservative groups are focusing on defending their incumbents in blue and purple states like New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Illinois. 
Still, the fastest-growing segment of the population is the independent vote. There are roughly 1 million unaffiliated voters in Colorado now, outnumbering registered Democrats and Republicans, so any candidate has to appeal to moderates.
Top Republicans believe Brauchler can.
“If the guy runs,” said Josh Penry, a former Republican leader of the Colorado state Senate, “we couldn’t do better.” 
Brauchler was elected to his current post in 2012, so he could run for reelection next year instead, or wait until 2018 and try for governor. A graduate of University of Colorado law school, he has spent most of his career as a prosecutor and litigator. Serving as a judge advocate general in the military, Brauchler was called to active duty in 2010 before being deployed to Iraq a year later. In 2012, he won his campaign to become district attorney for a Denver-area region with nearly 1 million people.
Brauchler gained notoriety — locally and nationally — for his aggressive pursuit to impose the death penalty on James Holmes in the Aurora shooting. But he’s also faced fierce criticism for drawing out the case: At least one juror refused to consent to the death penalty, leading to a hung jury and ultimately 12 life sentences for Holmes without parole. Critics said that Brauchler could have won the same deal before the trial, presumably saving millions in legal fees and avoiding the painful memories that were reopened.
The Colorado Criminal Defense Bar, which opposes the death penalty, said it was “extremely disheartened by the wastefulness of the trial, which could have been avoided two years ago when a plea was offered that would have produced the exact same result.”
But Brauchler was unapologetic, saying the demands made by the “life for murder crowd” to drop the pursuit of the death penalty were “outrageous.”
“That’s not justice,” Brauchler said. “It was justice to seek death, and it would have been justice had he received death.”
Five Republicans have already announced to run for the Senate seat, but none so far is seen as viable, intensifying the focus on Brauchler. If he opts out, an array of local officials, state legislators, business executives and potentially even U.S. congressmen are expected to consider jumping in.
One is Rep. Scott Tipton. A spokesman said the Republican lawmaker is planning to run for reelection at the moment but “is not going to close the door on any opportunity.”



            By 
Nick Gass
             and 
Aaron MaK

Another is Romney nephew Doug Robinson, a managing director of the audit and tax consultancy KPMG who chaired the 2012 White House hopeful’s campaign in Colorado.
“I have had some friends in the community approach me about it, and I am thinking whether this would be right for Colorado and right for my family,” Robinson said in an email. He noted he would put “some” of his own cash into a potential Senate bid but would raise “a lot” given the tens of millions of dollars it would take to run.
Bennet has kept a low profile in the Senate, though he nabbed a slot on the influential Finance Committee and ran Senate Democrats' campaign arm last cycle. He was also a central player in the attempt to pass comprehensive immigration reform in the last Congress, which ultimately stalled but could play well for him among the state's growing Latino population.
Republicans see a chance to tether Bennet to an unpopular president, given the Democrat’s support for much of the Obama agenda. While he praises Obamacare and notes he "approves" of President Barack Obama's performance in office, Bennet says he’s had his tangles with the White House — bucking the president, for example, on a 2012 budget deal.
Whatever Bennet’s perceived weaknesses, several Republicans have already declined to challenge him — none more important than Coffman, who represents a critical battleground district in the Denver suburbs.
Exacerbating the Republican dilemma is the turmoil that’s engulfed the state party this year. In the spring, the two-term state party chairman, Ryan Call, was ousted by a tea party-backed insurgency behind the campaign of Steve House. But later, the state’s attorney general, Cynthia Coffman, and former Rep. Tom Tancredo turned on House and sought his ouster from the job.
House alleged that the GOP officials sought to spread false rumors accusing him of infidelity, a jaw-dropping charge tantamount to blackmail that played out in the Colorado press for weeks earlier this summer.
Many Republicans are nervous the party's infighting could be problematic come 2016, particularly in the Senate race.
“It’s a tough path, a steep path, and it’s made all the more difficult by a challenging political environment and dysfunctional state party,” Call said.In an interview, House downplayed the disputes, saying he’s traveled across the state to foster party unity and build a robust operation to improve his party’s chances in 2016.
“As far as I’m concerned, it was an intrafamily disagreement, and we’ve resolved it,” he said.
But Republicans say the one thing can truly unify the party is winning in 2016 — and that Brauchler represents their best shot. 
His allies argue that Brauchler’s courtroom chops and speaking skills — he has brought more than 140 cases to verdict — would translate well to the campaign trail. Though he's relatively inexperienced as a candidate — Brauchler lost a 2008 bid for DA, the only other time he's run for elected office — he was courted during the 2014 election cycle to challenge Gov. John Hickenlooper. The Democratic incumbent stayed the execution of a man on death row for his 1993 murder of four people at a Chuck E. Cheese restaurant in Aurora, and Brauchler won over many Republicans with his sharp-edged criticism of Hickenlooper.
But while Brauchler is quick on his feet, he’s a blank slate politically. That could cut both ways. He lacks a voting record that could be picked apart on the campaign trail, but he’s also never endured the rigors of such a high-profile election.
Asked about his ideology, Brauchler said, “I feel like I’m a conservative.” 
He went on to note that he opposes abortion, when asked about his position.
“This is something that nobody cares about when you run for DA,” Brauchler said with a laugh. “Nobody ever asks you if you are in favor of Roe vs. Wade. I’m a DA, man! We don’t prosecute that, that’s not my thing.”

Manu Raju is senior congressional reporter for Politico.

                                            By 
                                                    Katy Reckdahl


                                            By 
JR Ross


                                            By 
John Parmentola
                                             and 
Theodore A. Postol


                                            By 
Nahal Toosi

 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: The GOP pins its hopes on the prosecutor in the Aurora theater massacre case.
title: Chaos in Colorado risks key Senate seat for GOP
